scenario:
Shares in GE Aerospace rose by more than 63% in 2024 after adjusting for the spinoff of GE Vernova. The commercial aerospace industry helped dispel fears of a slowdown in original equipment sales due to Boeing and Airbus falling short of airplane production expectations and ongoing supply chain and parts availability issues. 

GE Aerospace's commercial engine orders held up well despite issues delivering engines last year. Strength in service orders and better-than-expected margin performance led management to hike its earnings guidance throughout the year. 

GE's management started the year with an operating profit expectation of $6.25 billion, ending it with an expectation of $6.8 billion. Segment profit guidance for Commercial Engines & Services (CES) increased from $6 billion to $6.8 billion, while Defense & Propulsion Technologies (DPT) remained steady at $1 billion to $1.3 billion.

In 2025, GE Aerospace is expected to be in great shape with services, but margins could be pressured as it needs to ramp up LEAP deliveries. Management's guidance for the defense segment profit is at the lower end of the range, suggesting some margin pressure. The company's guidance for 2025 could be mixed. 

Key financial data points for 2024 include: 
- Commercial engine orders held up well despite issues delivering engines last year
- Strength in service orders and better-than-expected margin performance led to increased earnings guidance
- Segment profit guidance for CES increased from $6 billion to $6.8 billion
- Segment profit guidance for DPT remained steady at $1 billion to $1.3 billion

Key financial data points for 2025 include: 
- GE Aerospace is expected to be in great shape with services
- Margins could be pressured as it needs to ramp up LEAP deliveries
- Management's guidance for the defense segment profit is at the lower end of the range, suggesting some margin pressure.
